evidence.text:
Person A: No harm, no foul! Oh, it’s so good to see you, Thel. You look terrific.
Person A: I think about Teddy often. Such a special guy. What’s it been, two years now?
Person B: Just about two.
Person A: Five since Sheryl. Still feels like a dream. How are you holding up?

Person B: Let’s not be maudlin. You gonna show me your place?
Person A: Got a TV. Plants. Window-- You mind? Most infections start from the hands. I read that. Our director’s been trying to get me to touch Gloria in the scene where I adopt her. But I won’t do it.

Person B: My grandson is parked a block away. I don’t have much time...
Person B: He’s 24.
Person A: I need to be back by eight! It’s opening night. I can’t miss it.

Person B: We’re stopping by Mona’s.
Person B: That was a fun trip, wasn’t it? When was that-- ‘95?
Person B: Whatever you say, buddy. If you’re right, maybe we can use it. Then--
Person B: To get a gun.
Person B: It’s just a precaution! A couple of shmegeggies like us turning up unannounced? I like to be prepared.
Person B: How hard could it be? Idiots use them all the time.
Person B: So what if we get there and he has a gun? Then what?
Person B: You’ll have to distract her. Mona’s still sharp. It’s not gonna be so easy.
Person A: Good to see you, doll.
Person B: ANNIE, GET YOUR BLASTED, FLEA￾RIDDEN, GODDAMN HOUND OUT OF MY

Person A: What is it with you-- you miss that place?
Person B: I like it there.
Person B: Sheryl used to cook. Pick up our socks, keep the place together. I’ll take help where I can get it. I’m not ashamed. God forbid someone makes life a little easier, right?
Person A: It’s not the same.

Person A: Isn’t that interesting. They’re different Gary’s. But both Gary.
Person A: I guess we don’t.
Person B: It’s my grandson.

Person A: If I listened to you I’d be your roommate by now! Go home, Ben. You don’t want to be here.
Person B: What about your grandson?
Person A: ...No, no--
Person B: We’re the only ones left, Thel.
Person B: The least we can do is take care of each other. Call your family.
Person B: I am sorry. About all of it. We gave it a good try didn’t we?

Person B: I lived with my parents until I was 23. Then I moved in with Teddy. And I lived with him until I was 91. I’ve lived, just me, for two years now. It’s lonely sometimes. I miss Teddy. But I tried sushi. And I liked that quite a bit. I’ve enjoyed my time alone. I guess I wanted more.
Person B: I think I know her.
Person B: Lois?
Person A: There is no show without Daddy Warbucks.

Person B: ...You want bread? We have bread. Ben pulls a piece of bread in a ziploc out of his jacket pocket. They tear it in half and share it.
Person A: It’s like a rock.
Person A: Come on, we’re gonna lose him.
Person A: Keep a lookout. I’m gonna try to talk to them. If things get funny, you go for help.
Person B: Thel? ...Thelma?
Person A: Talk to me, Thel! What’s going on?
Person B: I’m terribly sorry for the imposition...

Person A: I beat him up.
Person B: What is this? A shoe?
Person B: I x’d it!

Person B: Don’t take people’s money. Clean up your store. Be nicer to Michael.
Person B: And don’t smoke.
Person B: I hope you know I’ll be buying you a new scooter. And a new phone.
Person B: Both good options. We’ll make a plan, dear.
